history.content:
I think it's recommended to take easier classes your first semester so you can "adjust" to college, whatever that means for you. Some people can easily handle 4 technical classes every semester, some people find it a bit tougher. I'd recommend going a bit lighter your first semester just to be sure, so you can explore other opportunities on campus. Also if is too hard, because you only have one semester, if you tank some classes your GPA is really going to show it.

Two technical courses your first semester should be fine though. You'll probably want to look into some humanities/DeCal's or something for your other classes.



-----


Just a heads up on the math stuff, if you've taken Calc AB in high school then I would suggesting skipping out of Math 1A because upperdiv cs classes generally don't use the calculus from 1A/B beyond calculating simple derivatives/integrals. Most EECS theory classes require a strong foundation on linear algebra (Math 54, EE 16A/B), and probability/discrete math (CS 70) so I would focus on understanding those math concepts instead (so maybe take EE16A or Math 1B instead :) )


————

If you got a 5 or even a 4 in Calc AB I would highly suggest going right to Math 1B. Or take EE16A and save Math 1B for the spring or even community college in the summer, this year or next. As mentioned above, other than basic derivatives and integrals, not much other than basic Calc is needed in CS classes.  CS 189 does require MV Calc though.


The more important thing, especially if you’re chasing the 3.3 for CS qualification, is to do well in CS61A.  You don’t want to get behind the 8-ball with a bad grade. CS61A is at least 10x more involved and harder than AP CS A. The best way to prepare for this class is to actually thoroughly go thru the materials and do the homework from a previous semester.  Prof DeNero is a god though as a lecturer, he is that good. But be prepared to work you a$$ off in order to get a good grade.

I think it's recommended to take easier classes your first semester so you can "adjust" to college, whatever that means for you. Some people can easily handle 4 technical classes every semester, some people find it a bit tougher. I'd recommend going a bit lighter your first semester just to be sure, so you can explore other opportunities on campus. Also if is too hard, because you only have one semester, if you tank some classes your GPA is really going to show it.

Two technical courses your first semester should be fine though. You'll probably want to look into some humanities/DeCal's or something for your other classes.

children.subject: Should be pretty chill semester since youve had cs and the equivalent of math 1a in high school.

history.content: I took calc ab and cs in high school. I think I'm pretty decent at CS but I am a little worried that this might be a terrible idea for first semester because I don't see this recommended anywhere.
history.subject: Is taking CompSci 61A and Math 1A together first semester going to cause problems later?
